ratings.comment: Not a bad professor necessarily, just INSANELY boring. Engelman doesn't put much (if any) effort into making lectures interesting. Not really a hard professor. Essays were graded very easily and tests were all multiple choice and not too hard. I wouldn't recommend due to how boring she is, but if you want an easy A/AB and can put up, go for it.

Great professor! She made the transition to online during COVID-19 very easy and streamlined the syllabus to make sure we learned the most necessary information. The concepts learned were mostly common sense and easily applicable to everyday life. Her lectures were easy to follow along and make sense of.

I absolutely loved Prof. Engelman! Her lectures were very insightful and helped to talk about a lot of modern issues. The class is fairly easy as long as you go to lecture and discussion; however, she does upload all the slides from lecture. There is a lot of reading for this course but most of it can be skimmed over pretty quickly.

Prof Engelmans lectures, jam-packed with well-organised facts, exemplify their expertise in their field and their ability to effectively communicate course concepts to the audience. Workload is minimal, usually 6 hours a week. Read the readings, pay attention in lecture, and it should be an easy A.

This class is based on her lectures and readings she finds on the internet. Her lectures are quite boring and she wasn't very engaging. The readings were sometimes EXTREMELY long. Oh, I can't forget to mention that there are 2 quizzes per week on the readings. The whole class is graded on 2 exams, 2 writing assignments, the quizzes, and participato

Somehow finds a way to make a 50 minute lecture feel like a power lecture. Often condescends when she teaches and insults our intelligence with the level of unnecessary detail she puts into everything. Requires weekly quizzes to be taken before you get to class, so you only learn what you need to know after youre graded on it

Not my favorite class, but ok for an ethnic studies. The class material is very dry and was not at all what I expected. Exams unnecessarily hard and discussion somewhat useless, but is mandatory as participation is apart of your grade. Weekly reading and quizzes unnecessarily long and can be very annoying and pointless at times.
Lectures were straightforward but kind of dry, and powerpoint slides were posted right after lecture. The topics were pretty interesting, but the exams were weirdly detailed and difficult.

She was fine. Nothing much to complain about or compliment. For me, I was concerned that in a sociology class, we would be learning more of the professors opinions than facts. I am pleased to say that this is not really the case with Engelman. The readings are a bit more polarized, but the professor herself is very unbiased and factual.

Lectures can be sometimes run on a little long but the content is usually pretty interesting. You have weekly homework assignments where you have to read articles (sometimes very long ones) then answer a 3 question quiz on them which can be annoying at times. Overall, this is a pretty good and interesting ethnic studies class and isn't too hard.

One of my favorite professors at UW Madison. Really knows her stuff and the class is super interesting; she's very kind and understanding as well. Expect to do work, but you'll enjoy the work you're doing.

Michal is an excellent professor with very clear expectations. I took this course as a fulfillment for a certificate and loved it! Two essay exams (she gives you a very helpful study guide ahead of time), one final paper, and weekly reading posts. If you do the assigned readings and go to class it is not difficult to get an A.

This professor is organized and has clear lecture content and class structure. The concepts are pretty straightforward and the lectures dwell on the same simple ideas for too long. However, the ideas are important and very relevant to real world problems happening right now. The exams were fair and quite easy. This is a good ethnics studies class.
Interesting lectures

Prof. Engelman's lectures are boring and cover mostly common sense information. The readings are long, but only contain a few important details, so learn to skim. Overall, the class is an extremely easy A.

Michal was an amazing lecturer, however lectures are not necessarily terribly interesting, but she displays the information well. All readings are done online and are usually quite dense. Papers are easy, exams somewhat difficult as they ask very specific questions about the many readings. Ok course.

Michal is an excellent lecturer and did a great job of making what I thought was pretty dry material interesting. There are only two exams and two papers for the class. Discussion is mandatory but also extremely helpful, if you use the study guides from discussion you'll be fine for the exams. Cross your fingers for a good TA!
Very easy class. Lectures are interesting. Would highly recommend for ethnic study fulfillment.
As long as you do the readings for this class, you'll be golden for the two exams and the two 300 word essays!

Interesting class, but lectures seem so long even thought they are only 50 minutes. 2 papers worth 15% each, graded by TA's, most get around 90's. 2 midterms, no final. 1st midterm is hard (25% grade) second was much easier (35% grade). 10% participation in section, and 1 extra credit paper for 2% of grade.

Michal scared me but by the end of the semester I like her. The lectures get more interesting as the class goes on, there's no book, just online readings which are long but you have to do them because the tests are pretty complex. There's two short papers and one extra credit paper. Overall the class was fine, good for an ethnic requirement

Professor Engelman is knowledgeable on the topics presented, but she speeds through lectures. She sometimes comes across as harsh and unapproachable, and her lectures and test reviews will not fully prepare you for the in-depth exams.

Excellent lecturer. She clearly cares and knows a lot about what she's teaching, which makes it easy to stay interested and learn. The class is heavy on connecting theories & ideas to scientific studies & statistics, so be prepared to use critical thinking skills. 2 easy, short papers + 2 straightforward multiple choice exams + 1 extra credit essay

Professor Engelman is the most engaging lecturer I've had in college. Every lecture is like a TED Talk. She is passionate about what she teaches and provides students with primary sources for the data and research addressed. I'm not a sociology major, but I hope to take another one of her courses before graduating.

This course was easier than most of my high school classes.  All you need to do to get an A is show up to lecture and pay attention.  The 3 writing assignments are very easy and short; most get A's.  There are only 2 midterm tests, which are straightforward, and no final.  Test averages were B's.  Overall, she is a great lecturer.
Exams are easy for those who study. The material is very interesting and the lectures are well prepared. No textbook required.
Very interesting course. The current structure, however, was poorly designed.  Poor information on what to understand from readings.  Would be much better with a textbook.
Lots of readings that most people don't do. Over 20+ pages of readings every lecture assigned to you. Most of the material is covered in graphs for some reason? Like just give me the definition.

Definitely the best professor I've ever had in sociology...I was very confused about sociology before taking this class, and now I love the subject. Well-structured syllabus, enjoyable lectures, and reasonable workload. She has great clarity of thinking - when she talks, she edits herself and tries to be accurate. Extra points for her humor too!!
Lots of reading, but you figure out how to skim after a while. First test was brutal, but she curved. A good choice for the ethnic requirement, I think.

Well, she can teach, in the sense that she can give you information.  She however doesn't seem to understand that a lecture should be given all in one day, not two disjointed halves of occasionally unrelated material in one day.  She also assigns 20-60 pages of readings for EVERY lecture, readings which are seldom dealt with in class.

She has high expectations for a 100 level class. For each lecture you are expected to read 2-4 articles ranging from 5-30 pages each. Her lectures contain a lot of graphs. The exams compromise of specific data from these graphs as well as info from the readings. The exam was curved significantly and extra credit was provided.

She's incredibly knowledgeable but struggles to convey that knowledge to students in a lecture setting. Tests are mostly multiple choice but extremely difficultspecific. There are a lot of assigned readings, most of which you never talk about or see on the test. The material is very interesting however, it's a shame the class is poorly structure
Be prepared to read a novel before every class, and then once in class be prepared to not talk about anything you just read.

Michal understands the concepts she teaches at such a high level, but she does often forget who she's teaching.  She definitely wants her students to learn the content and share her passion, so she's definitely willing to clarify the topics.  Her tests are unpredictable, but the content of her course is extremely interesting.

The concepts from lecture were common sense but the test would only use application of the concepts which we did not talk about. The readings are extremely long and she asks very specific questions about them on exams. She had to curve every test drastically so people could pass the tests. I don't recommend her or the class.

I took this class just for the Ethnic requirement.  Michal was a decent lecturer especially for being new at it.  I followed her power points and lectures well, and discussion sections cleared up any confusion.  Three easy writing assignments that don't take too long.  I missed a few lectures and still did OK on exams. Would recommend for ethnic

Class is boring and lectures are long. Three 300 word papers, they were graded pretty easily once the TA's saw the exam averages. Tests are difficult and all over the place, but extremely curved. I got a 70%  and it was an A. Also, one 500 word extra credit paper for up to 5%. It was her first time teaching so she might switch things up.

A lot of students complain that this class is really dry, but I enjoyed it. Prof. Engelman is always well-prepared and the concepts are quite easy. There are only 3 300 word writing assignments and the multiple choice tests weren't hard at all. Even if you did poorly on the tests, she curved them pretty generously. Would recommend.

I don't think that she deserves all the negative attention that she gets. This was her first time teaching the class, so obviously her curriculum and syllabus won't be ideal. She talks fast but is very well-spoken. Exams were tricky this semester but she acknowledged that this will change. Very helpful if you talk to her one-on-one.

This class was recommended to me for ethnic studies credit by a friend, but I found it to be poorly organized.  Instead of a textbook, there were dozens of long, unnecessary readings.  The tests were extremely difficult to study for, and as a result, much of the class did poorly.  I would recommend looking for a different ethnic studies course.

I can not express how much I hate this class. Do yourself a favor and don't sign up for it unless you like reading 300 page readings every week. The tests are based on insignificant details from the readings and it's almost impossible to prepare for them.

This was her first semester teaching this course, and it definitely showed. She did not have control of the classroom, and often struggled to keep the students' attention. Lectures are extremely dry (try staying awake when she turns the lights off every day). The readings! Wow, a ridiculous amount of reading that often becomes unnecessary.
Lectures are boring and prolonged, while the tests are impossible and nothing like the provided study guide.  She doesn't know what she is talking about most of the time. Don't take this class.

Get ready to read novels for each test. Hard to study for her tests as they are all over the place. Long and pointless readings no one does. Shes very smart but this class is taken for an easy A while she runs the show as a 500 graduate level class. Information is interesting but presented poorly. Find a different professor for the class.

I honestly hate this class. I thought it was going to be easy, but it is horribly boring and harder than expected. She takes herself too seriously for the level of this class. The articles are SO long and there are SO many of them. The exams are hard to prepare for, her lectures are dull, and sometimes she is very hard to follow. Not fun or easy.

The readings are long, disconnected, and hardly referenced during lecture. By around 25 minutes into her lecture it is impossible to figure out what she is talking about as she never stops talking. Her slides are either graphs with ridiculously tiny text or walls of words that she doesn't read. Bullet points and main points are not to be found.
Lectures were basically common sense information. The readings are long and pointless and basically summarize lecture again. Tests are nothing like the lecture or study guide provided.

The readings provided are long, dull, and never referenced to again. If you do read them you'll realize that the material is just a rehash of the same thing in lecture. The exams are difficult to study for, and the writing assignment's criteria are vague. She can talk fast so don't miss key points since they are not on the slides provided.
